# 16 Days of Activism against Gender-based Violence

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/16_Days_of_Activism_campaign_-
_Solomon_Islands_%2814038247499%29.jpg/343px-16_Days_of_Activism_campaign_-
_Solomon_Islands_%2814038247499%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:16_Days_of_Activism_campaign_-
_Solomon_Islands_\(14038247499\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:16_Days_of_Activism_campaign_-
_Solomon_Islands_\(14038247499\).jpg "Enlarge")

Women from Lord House Settlement community March in the opening parade for 16
Days of Activism Against Gender Based Violence. Photo:UN Women/Marni Gilbert

**16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence** is an international
campaign to challenge [violence against women](/wiki/Violence_against_women
"Violence against women") and girls.[1] The campaign runs every year from 25
November, the [International Day for the Elimination of Violence against
Women](/wiki/International_Day_for_the_Elimination_of_Violence_against_Women
"International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women"), to 10
December, [Human Rights Day](/wiki/Human_Rights_Day "Human Rights Day"). It
was initiated in 1991 by the first Women's Global Leadership Institute, held
by the [Center for Women's Global
Leadership](/wiki/Center_for_Women%27s_Global_Leadership "Center for Women's
Global Leadership") (CWGL) at [Rutgers University](/wiki/Rutgers
"Rutgers").[2][1]

Currently, more than 3,700 organizations from approximately 164 countries
participate in the campaign annually.

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 Significant Dates
  * 2 Themes
  * 3 References
  * 4 External links

## Significant
Dates[[edit](/w/index.php?title=16_Days_of_Activism_against_Gender-
based_Violence&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Significant Dates")]

  * November 25 - [International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women](/wiki/International_Day_for_the_Elimination_of_Violence_against_Women "International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women")
  * November 29 - International Women Human Rights Defenders Day
  * December 1 - [World AIDS Day](/wiki/World_AIDS_Day "World AIDS Day")
  * December 5 - [International Volunteer Day for Economic and Social Development](https://www.un.org/en/events/volunteerday/)
  * December 6 - Anniversary of the [Montreal Massacre](/wiki/%C3%89cole_Polytechnique_massacre "École Polytechnique massacre"), which is observed as the [National Day of Remembrance and Action on Violence Against Women](/wiki/National_Day_of_Remembrance_and_Action_on_Violence_Against_Women "National Day of Remembrance and Action on Violence Against Women") in Canada
  * December 10 - [International Human Rights Day](/wiki/International_Human_Rights_Day "International Human Rights Day") and the anniversary of the [Universal Declaration of Human Rights](/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights "Universal Declaration of Human Rights")

## Themes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=16_Days_of_Activism_against_Gender-
based_Violence&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Themes")]

Every year, the 16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence Campaign
either introduces a new theme, or continues an old theme. The theme focuses on
one particular area of gender inequality and works to bring attention to these
issues and make changes that will have an impact. The Center for Women's
Global Leadership sends out a "Take Action Kit" every year, detailing how
participants can get involved and campaign in order to make a change.[3]

  * The first campaign theme in 1991 was entitled _Violence Against Women Violates Human Rights,_ and women from around the world came together with the Center for Women's Global Leadership at the first International Women's Leadership Institute.[4] The theme was used again in 1992.[5]
  * In 1993, the third campaign's second theme was _Democracy in the Family, Democracy of Families, Democracy for Every Body._[6]
  * The 1994 theme brought back the first theme, but with a minor change. It was entitled _Awareness, Accountability, Action: Violence Against Women Violates Human Rights._[7]
  * The 1995 theme, _Vienna, Cairo, Copenhagen, and Beijing: Bringing Women 's Human Rights Home,_ focused on four major conferences, including the [_Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing_](https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/beijing/) (September, 1995), which was "the third major UN conference since the _[World Conference on Human Rights in Vienna](http://www.ohchr.org/EN/ABOUTUS/Pages/ViennaWC.aspx)_ (1993)," and "...follows the _[International Conference on Population and Development](/wiki/International_Conference_on_Population_and_Development "International Conference on Population and Development")_ (Cairo, 1994), and the _[World Summit on Social Development](https://www.un.org/esa/socdev/wssd/text-version/)_ (Copenhagen, 1995)."[8]
  * As a follow up to the 1995 themes and major conferences within recent years, the 1996 theme was _Bringing Women 's Human Rights Home: Realizing Our Visions._[9]
  * _The 1997 Campaign was Demand Human Rights in the Home and the World,_ which was working towards the 1998 [Global Campaign for Women's Human Rights](http://wwda.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/intnetwhr1.pdf).[10]
  * The theme for the campaign in 1998 was _Building a Culture of Respect for Human Rights._[11]
  * The 1999 campaign theme was entitled _Fulfilling the Promise of Freedom from Violence._[12]
  * In 2000, the theme was _Celebrating the 10th Anniversary of the Campaign,_ in which participants would review the accomplishments of the last 10 years of the campaign and build upon those achievements. The Center also asked participants to send in documentation of their work in order to initiate a project to document the efforts of the campaign.[13]
  * The campaign theme in 2001 was _Racism and Sexism: No More Violence._[14]
  * The campaign theme in 2002 was _Creating a Culture that Says No to Violence Against Women._[15]
  * The 2003 campaign, _Violence Against Women Violates Human Rights: Maintaining the Momentum Ten Years After Vienna (1993-2003),_ was focused on reviewing changes that had occurred in the 10 years since the [Vienna Declaration](/wiki/Vienna_Declaration_and_Programme_of_Action "Vienna Declaration and Programme of Action") that was a result of the _World Conference on Human Rights in Vienna_ (1993) and the [UN General Assembly's](/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly "United Nations General Assembly") adoption of the [Declaration on the Elimination of Violence Against Women](/wiki/Declaration_on_the_Elimination_of_Violence_Against_Women "Declaration on the Elimination of Violence Against Women") (2003).[16]
  * The 2004-2005 campaign was entitled _For the Health of Women, for the Health of the World: No More Violence,_ particularly focused on the "intersection of violence against women and the HIV/AIDS pandemic."[17]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/16_Days_of_Activism_campaign_-
_Solomon_Islands_%2814221599901%29.jpg/420px-16_Days_of_Activism_campaign_-
_Solomon_Islands_%2814221599901%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:16_Days_of_Activism_campaign_-
_Solomon_Islands_\(14221599901\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:16_Days_of_Activism_campaign_-
_Solomon_Islands_\(14221599901\).jpg "Enlarge")

16 Days of Activism to raise awareness of the various forms of violence
against women

  * The 2006 campaign, _Celebrate 16 Years of 16 Days: Advance Human Rights <\--> End Violence Against Women,_ celebrated not only those who had contributed to the campaign, but those who had given their lives or suffered violence during their fight against gender inequality.[18]

  * The 2007 campaign was entitled _Demanding Implementation, Challenging Obstacles: End Violence Against Women._[19]
  * The 2008 campaign title was _Human Rights for Women <\--> Human Rights for All: UDHR60_, which celebrated the 60th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.[20]
  * The 2009 theme was _Commit, Act, Demand: We CAN End Violence Against Women!_[21]
  * The theme in 2010 marked the 20th year of the 16 Days of Activism Against Gender Violence Campaign, and was entitled _Structures of Violence: Defining the Intersections of Militarism and Violence Against Women._[22]
  * From 2011 to 2014, the theme of the campaign was _From Peace in the Home to Peace in the World: Let 's Challenge Militarism and End Violence Against Women!_[23]
  * In 2015 and 2016, the theme of the campaign was _From Peace in the Home to Peace in the World: Make Education Safe for All!_[24][25]

qa.question: when does the 16 days of activism campaign start

m.0d0vqn_728.Query Analysis: The query asks for the starting date of the 16 days of activism campaign.
m.0d0vqn_728.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the historical context of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, particularly their exits from a union in the 16th century and subsequent conflicts, especially with Russia and the remaining union of Denmark and Norway.
m.0d0vqn_728.Document and Query Keywords Matching: None of the query keywords ('16 days of activism', 'start date') are found in the document.
m.0d0vqn_728.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: None of the answer keywords ('25 November') are found in the document.
m.0d0vqn_728.Key Information Matching: There is no matching key information related to the query or the answer in the document.
m.0d0vqn_728.Can the Document Answer the Query: No, the document does not contain any information about the 16 days of activism campaign or its start date.
m.0d0vqn_728.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: No, the document provides no relevant context or additional information related to the query.
m.0d0vqn_728.Explanation: The document is entirely unrelated to the query. It focuses on historical events involving Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, with no mention of the 16 days of activism campaign or any relevant dates. Therefore, it cannot assist in answering the query or providing useful context.

tat_669_3.Query Analysis: The query asks for the starting date of the '16 Days of Activism' campaign.
tat_669_3.Answer Analysis: The answer is 25 November, indicating the campaign starts on that date.
tat_669_3.Document Content Analysis: The document provides detailed information about network quality, sales execution, subscriber base management, and various performance metrics related to a mobile network service in 2019. It includes data on prepaid and postpaid activations, churn rates, net activations, and subscriber totals.
tat_669_3.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document does not contain any keywords related to '16 Days of Activism' or 'start date'.
tat_669_3.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document does not mention '25 November' in the context of the campaign or any related topic.
tat_669_3.Key Information Matching: There is no key information in the document that matches the query or the answer. The document focuses entirely on mobile network performance metrics and does not touch on social campaigns or specific dates related to such campaigns.
tat_669_3.Can the Document Answer the Query: No, the document does not provide any information about the '16 Days of Activism' campaign or its start date.
tat_669_3.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: No, the document does not contain any relevant information that could help infer details about the '16 Days of Activism' campaign.
tat_669_3.Explanation: The document is entirely unrelated to the query. It focuses on mobile network performance and does not provide any context or information about social campaigns, including the '16 Days of Activism' campaign. Therefore, it is deemed irrelevant.
